Introduction

Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) are hyperpigmented lesions that are present at birth or appear within the first few months of life.  These nevi are due to melanocyte proliferation and vary in size, with larger lesions carrying an increased risk for malignant transformation.

Pathogenesis



CMNs are caused by a benign proliferation of melanocyte cells.  In contrast to the familial and ultraviolet-related pathogenesis of acquired nevi, CMNs likely arise from abnormal migration or proliferation of melanocytes as they migrate from the neural crest to the epidermis.  Most cases are sporadic, but large CMNs are associated with somatic mutations in the NRAS gene during embryonic development.



Histologically, clusters of melanocytes in CMNs can extend from the epidermis to the dermis, subcutaneous fat, or muscle, with extension along hair follicles and sweat glands.

Classification



CMNs are classified based on size:



  • Small:  <1.5 cm.
  • Medium:  1.5-20 cm.
  • Large/giant:  >20 cm.


Increasing size is correlated with an increased risk for complications (eg, malignant transformation).

Clinical presentation



CMNs present at birth or within the first few months of life as hyperpigmented lesions, often with an increased density of overlying dark, coarse hairs (hypertrichosis) (

image 1
).  They may appear initially as flat, homogenous hyperpigmentations but often grow rapidly during infancy and become heterogeneously pigmented and raised.



The distribution of CMNs can involve any part of the body, with the trunk and extremities often affected.  They are most commonly small- or medium-sized, asymptomatic, and isolated; large CMNs may be associated with satellite nevi (smaller scattered nevi surrounding the primary lesion) (

image 2
).

Differential diagnosis



  • Acquired melanocytic nevi (
    image 3
    ):  Lesions of benign melanocyte proliferation that develop after the first few months of life are referred to as acquired melanocytic nevi.  These are generally small (<1 cm), brown macules that become raised over time and carry a small risk for malignant transformation.  The age of onset differentiates acquired melanocytic nevi from small CMNs.
  • Caf√© au lait macules (
    image 4
    ):  These lesions are flat and uniformly hyperpigmented without overlying hypertrichosis.
  • Congenital dermal melanocytosis (formerly called "mongolian spots") (
    figure 1
    ):  These flat, gray-blue patches are poorly circumscribed and classically located on the lower back and sacrum in infants.  The lesions fade with time and are not raised or associated with hypertrichosis.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of CMN is clinical based on the lesion's size and characteristic appearance in early infancy.  Dermoscopic findings, which are not unique to CMNs, include diffuse brown pigmentation, aggregated globules (round, evenly distributed pattern), or pigment network (grid-like, reticular pattern).

Prognosis and complications



The natural history of CMN is growth in proportion to body size over time.



The main complication is risk for malignant transformation to melanoma.  With the increasing size of a CMN, the risk for melanoma increases and the age of melanoma presentation decreases:  Small and medium CMNs carry a 1% risk and generally do not transform before puberty, whereas large CMNs carry a 5% risk and melanoma may develop during childhood.



Rarely, patients may develop neurocutaneous melanosis, which is characterized by melanocyte proliferation in the CNS.  The presentation may include hydrocephalus, seizures, and/or developmental delay, and the diagnosis is confirmed with MRI of the brain.  The risk for neurocutaneous melanosis is greatest with large CMNs.

Management



The mainstay of CMN treatment in most cases is observation and surveillance for melanoma with regular skin examinations.  Biopsy is performed for lesions that are rapidly growing, ulcerated, or painful/itchy.



Laser therapy and/or surgical excision can be considered for cosmetic or functional concerns, although scarring can occur.  The ability to excise a CMN is limited by size, and the risk for malignancy remains increased after excision of a large CMN, likely due to the extensive area often affected (including deeper structures such as fat and muscle).

Summary



Congenital melanocytic nevi present within the first few months of life as hyperpigmented patches of variable size with an increased density of hair follicles.  The diagnosis is clinical, and the mainstay of management includes serial monitoring for melanoma.
